text:
everyone welcome to pai's kitchen as many of you 
know I just came back from a trip to Japan to

Osaka and if you haven't seen my vlogs on that 
trip definitely check them out there was so much

good food so much fun I will link to them in the 
description box below so one of the dishes that

I fell in love with in Osaka was okonomiyaki 
or what a lot of people like to call Japanese

pizza I think it's more of a Japanese pancake but 
the thing is it's actually really easy to make at

home so that's what we're gonna do today I'm gonna 
share with you how you can bring Osaka into your

home with okonomiyaki alright let's get started 
so I'm gonna start with the batter so let's deal

with the dry ingredients first so I have here's 
just some all-purpose flour and to that I'm going

to add some cornstarch and the cornstarch will 
actually help reduce a total amount of gluten

which will prevent the pancake from getting too 
tough also I'm gonna add some baking powder give

that a whisk with a large whisk and a sprinkle 
of black pepper now let's talk about the wet

ingredients a couple things you might not be 
familiar with if you've not cooked up any food

before the very first thing is something called 
nagaimo yam okay and it's this sort of gnarly

looking thing right here and you can find this at 
Japanese grocery stores even like my tea and tea

for those of you Vancouver carries this as well 
so it's not as hard to find as you might think and

we'll talk about substitutes in a little bit but 
I want to keep the plastic on because sometimes if

you touch it with your bare hand it can make your 
skin a little itchy now I'm just gonna peel off

about a couple of inches and as you can see it's 
very slimy now I'm going to grate this Yemen as

you see it becomes even slimy or substance yes I 
know it does not look appetizing but trust me it

makes a difference in the texture of the batter 
this is what prevents the pancake from becoming

dense and doughy it will keep the dough sort of 
luscious and soft and on a custard on the inside

now if you don't have this it's not a deal-breaker 
you can make okonomiyaki without it I will go into

more details about sort of the pros and cons and 
what you can use and said in the written recipe

if you have ideas for substitution something that 
has worked for you in the past definitely let us

know in the comments below and I'm just gonna do 
this like just pile it on it's super fun to work

with so our next liquid ingredient is actually 
dashi which is a Japanese fish broth that's made

from kombu seaweed and dried bonito flakes but 
most home cooks just use a dashi powder which is

very convenient you can find it at grocery stores 
Asian grocery stores the inside looks like little

granules like that and all you have to do is just 
mix this in some plain water and you've got your

dashi instantly into the flour mixture and I'm 
just gonna stir this until it's mixed don't over

mix it you don't want tough doughy pancakes now 
ideally you want to let this rest for at least

half an hour you can leave this overnight and 
make finish the whole thing tomorrow if you'd

like but that rest period will allow the gluten 
to relax and further softening and tenderizing

our pancake okonomiyaki means to grill whatever 
you want basically so all of these things that I'm

adding a very classic but you can feel free to add 
whatever you want to this batter but definitely

one thing that is common all across Osaka style 
okonomiyaki is cabbage okay so I've got here lots

and lots of cabbage that I've chopped now it's 
gonna look like way more than you need but trust

me this is what keeps it tender it will prevent 
the pancake from being all doughy and flowery and

then lots of green onions and in terms of protein 
I want to add shrimp but you can add whatever you

want if you're gonna do chicken or pork what 
I would do is cook it off first then you don't

have to worry about whether it's cooked inside the 
pancake I know because the pancakes really thick

shrimp cooks so quickly so I don't ever have to 
worry about that now I'm also going to add pickled

ginger so this hot pink thing right here is called 
beni shoga and it's not the same ginger that come

your sushi okay that's a sweet pickle this is not 
sweet at all it's a spicy sort of tart salty kick

that'll help balance out all the rich flavors in 
here I'm going to add what's called tenkasu it's

basically deep fried tempura batter bits okay and 
what it's gonna do now it's crunchy kind of like

a rice krispy right now but when you add it in 
there it's not gonna keep it crispy because it

won't lad the crispness won't last in the batter 
but it will add pockets of air this will prevent

the pancake from being super dense and of course 
we've got to add a couple of eggs and I didn't get

to do this when I was in Osaka but sometimes you 
go to a restaurant you get to cook the okonomiyaki

yourself and then they'll come it'll come to you 
in a bowl like this with the batter on the bottom

and all the little fillings on top and you get 
to stir it and then cook it point though is you

don't want to mix this and then just kind of 
let it sit and hang out because these ten cups

of pieces will just kind of like disintegrate in 
your batter so you want to mix and then cook it

right away boom this is my favorite part of the 
whole thing and what do you like to put in your

okonomiyaki I would love to know let me know in 
the comments and that's it how easy is that right

so I've got a flat skillet here I'm gonna preheat 
it to about medium heat you don't want this to be

too hot because the batter is quite thick now you 
can make this as big or as small as you like as

long as you can flip it here you go and try to 
keep it round and definitely you don't want to

hear an aggressive sizzle when you put down the 
batter because that's your cue that it's too hot

now I like to keep mine about this size five six 
inches one because it's easier to flip two because

I find anymore than that it's just too much for 
me um like this is a good dinner size right here

a lot of times people like to put slices of pork 
belly on top so in North America it's hard to find

slices of plain pork belly but it's not hard 
to find bacon so that's what I'm gonna do and

it happens to be really delicious I mean why not 
put some bacon on it right yeah when we flip it

it will get nice and grilled there we go so this 
in my experience let it go slow and low about four

to five minutes per side beautiful bacon sizzle 
let's see what it looks like on the underside

ooh look at that now what I did the first time I 
flipped is actually the second time I flipped it

the first time I flipped I noticed that the bacon 
was peeling away a little bit so I just put extra

batter right there to glue it down so if you 
remember maybe when you place the bacon down

just put a little extra batter on top to help glue 
it down so it doesn't come off but that is it so

if you want to check if the inside is done you can 
do a toothpick test another thing that I like to

do is do a heat test so I take a fork or a knife 
or something and I poke it in the middle and they

let it sit there you know for a few seconds then I 
take it out and I put it at that's hot so if it's

hot then it's cooked there you go I mean don't 
touch it too long don't burn yourself all right

so I'm gonna flip it back because I think this 
side is prettier and let's finish it we are now

at the most important step of making okonomiyaki 
and that is to finish it with four toppings these

four toppings are so core to the character of 
okonomiyaki that if you just have cabbage and

batter but you've got these four things you're 
still good to go okay so first and very important

is the okonomiyaki sauce which comes in a bottle 
in a bag as the Japanese like to do it like this

now you could make your own but seriously most 
Japanese people just use this sauce and in order

to stay true to the flavor I would stick with the 
store-bought and I put some of that on careful it

comes out quicker than you think first time I 
was like that just put about this much and if

you feel it meets more you can add more later the 
second most important is well not second the other

most important is Japanese mayonnaise commonly 
known as QP Mayo this also comes in a bag which

don't have anymore do not use American mayonnaise 
for this it is so not the same make sure you get

yourself some Japanese Mayo and really load it 
on yeah next is something called our no D it's

basically Japanese seaweed crushed into little 
little tiny tiny pieces and I have just put it

in a sprinkler bottle here and I'm just gonna whoo 
yes it's a tiny little shaker bottle so you got to

be patient it's the price of tiny things there we 
go this one you gotta gotta have it's something

called Katsuobushi or a bonito flakes this is a 
key ingredient that's in the Japanese dashi stock

the flakes are of various sizes for toppings like 
this I like to get the ones with larger flakes

like that so it looks a little prettier and it's 
a nice smoky fish flavor oh yes if your pancake

is hot the steam will start to make the flakes 
dance which is not doing as much right now cuz I

waited too long getting ready to shoot this thing 
woohoo and now you've got yourself okonomiyaki

just want to show you the inside it should 
be packed with cabbage so it's not doughy

and dense oh no this piece doesn't have 
any bacon get a little bacon on there

it is such a Japanese flavor like there is 
no other cuisine that even approximates that

combination of flavor it's sweet and salty and 
just full of umami a lot of fish flavor from

the from the Katsuobushi and from the dashi as 
well Wow and the texture again this should not

be dull we are dense it should be soft with 
a lot of texture going on inside and luscious

and oh this is so good and it's so easy it might 
take you a couple of times to perfect the texture

but trust me it will be delicious I hope you 
give this a try the recipe as always will be

on pies kitchen comm and when you make it send 
me a photo on Facebook Twitter or Instagram and

make sure you watch my Asaka video to see what 
the original okonomiyaki that I had in Osaka

looked like the link to that is in the description 
below and if you haven't subscribed to the show

make sure you do so you don't miss an episode and 
click that little bell icon as well so you get a

notification every time I post a new video you 
love the show and you want to support us check

out our patreon link in the description below and 
I will see you next time for your next delicious
